chapter.title: Matrix Operations

subsection.title: Matrix Equality, Addition, Subtraction, and Scalar Multiplication
subsection.definition: Two matrices A and B are equal if they have equal dimensions m \times n, and each corresponding entries are equal, i.e. a_{ij} = b_{ij} for all i, j.

definition.title: Matrix addition
definition.p:
Let A, B be m \times n matrices (of the same dimension). Then, the sum of A and B, is the matrix formed by adding the corresponding entries of A and B. In other words,
\boxed{(A + B)_{ij} = \begin{bmatrix} a_{ij} + b_{ij} \end{bmatrix}}

subsection.p: Note that addition is only defined for matrices that have equal dimensions. Subtraction of matrices is defined similarly.
The previous definitions focussed on the considering matrices entry-wise (that is, entry-by-entry). The operations for a matrix can also be thought of in terms of vectors.

ul.li:
The sum A + B is the matrix whose columns are the sums of the corresponding columns of A and B, or,
A + B = \begin{bmatrix} \vec{a}_1 + \vec{b}_1 \amp \vec{a}_2 + \vec{b}_2 \amp \cdots \amp \vec{a}_n + \vec{b}_n \end{bmatrix}

The scalar multiple kA is the matrix whose columns are the scalar multiples of vectors k \vec{a}_j, or,
kA = \begin{bmatrix} k \vec{a}_1 \amp k \vec{a}_2 \amp \cdots \amp k \vec{a}_n \end{bmatrix}

subsection.p: In a similar way as vectors, (-1)A is denoted by -A, and also subtraction of matrices A - B is just A + (-1)B.

subsection.title: Properties of Matrix Addition
subsection.definition: An m \times n matrix whose entries are all zero is called a zero matrix, and is typically denoted by 0.
